video.title: The 2021 Games I Didn't Review (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*
2021 is over, another January wasteland stretches ahead of us like
the romantic comedy our partner forces us to endure before the
begrudging blowjob of the quarter one releases.
It&#39;s time for my second ever roundup of games I didn&#39;t review.
Last time I did this I did it before the awards episode in case I
wanted to sneak a dark horse candidate up the drainpipe to
clandestinely bugger expectations with its giant dark horse willy,
but in practice anything I don&#39;t review is most likely just fine
and not worth harping on about,
so that was like trying to add croutons to my salad by shaking my
keyboard over it.
So with expectations set nice and low, let&#39;s begin.
Unpacking
Some indie games are like hamsters on Viagra -
doing an awful lot with very little.
Case in point, here&#39;s everything you do in Unpacking -
you click on a moving in box and drag and drop all the contents
into shelves, cabinets and drawers.
Then you go to the next room and do it some more.
Pitch that in the elevator at Ubisoft and watch everyone&#39;s noses
wrinkle like you just blew a hole through the seat of your pants.
But it&#39;s actually rather enjoyable and zen and the crunchy
pastel-coloured isometric pixel art is pleasantly nostalgic like a
Game Boy Advance in the mouth of a friendly labrador.
Plus it&#39;s doing some interesting underhanded narrative stuff as you
notice what toys and kitchen appliances our unseen protagonist
keeps from move to move and what potential serial killers
they&#39;re moving in with.
Okay, it&#39;s no showstopper,
there&#39;s no heart-rending emotional storytelling going on,
but it&#39;s interesting. In a &quot;ooh they do chocolate brownie
M&amp;Ms now?&quot; sort of way.
Before Your Eyes
Oh you&#39;re holding out for heart-rending emotional storytelling,
are you?
Well, here&#39;s some: Before Your Eyes is a little snacky experience
centred around the gimmick that you have to point a webcam at
your face and control the game with blinking.
The premise is, you&#39;re going through the key memories of your
protagonist&#39;s life, jumping to the next one every time you blink.
Because you&#39;ve recently died and your life is literally flashing
&quot;before your eyes.&quot;
Title drop, y&#39;see.
I guess they couldn&#39;t have added &quot;flashing&quot; because people
might&#39;ve expected something else.
It is very overtly a gimmick game,
but one that&#39;s effectively using its gimmick to make a point
about how life must move on,
you&#39;re gonna have to blink at some point no matter how badly you
want to stay in this moment where you can see down your high
school english teacher&#39;s blouse.
And the story really sneaks up on your feely hole and rams
in the emotion cactus.
It is awkward to play &#39;cos you have to hold your head completely
still the whole time, and the software occasionally mistook simple
eye movements for blinks,
although that might be because I needed to light a few more
candles in the murky oubliette in which I dwell,
but I&#39;d recommend it to all you daywalkers out there.
Haven
I wish I&#39;d noticed this game when it came out &#39;cos it&#39;s by the
developers of Furi
and I liked that game enough I&#39;d let it snog one
of my close relatives.
One of the ugly ones, though, let&#39;s not go nuts.
Haven is a game about a young couple exploring an
alien world together, and it&#39;s honestly rather cute.
You don&#39;t see it much, do you, two protagonists who are just in a
relationship all game with equal billing and neither being murdered to
motivate the other.
It&#39;s just nice to watch them holding hands as they roller skate
across an alien landscape.
But then you have to stop roller skating for a JRPG-style random
encounter battle that completely kills the flow,
oh and it&#39;s one of those awful hybrid
turn based and real time systems, fuckup on fuckup, Haven,
I let the survival crafting elements slide &#39;cos I was sold on the
adorable space anime kids but now you&#39;ve killed my interest.
I very nearly reviewed it as part of a triple bill indie review that I
was planning to call &quot;The Roller Skating In Space Trilogy.&quot;
EXO ONE
The second game of which drops the combat, and the survival,
and all forms of organic life, anime or otherwise, and one of the
roller skates and most of the remaining one.
In EXO ONE you play a fucking ball bearing rolling around a series
of empty deserts, but it completely sucked me in.
You hold down a button to become really heavy,
then release it to become light again.
Sort of an oblique metaphor for one&#39;s emotional state while
reading the news.
And by this method alone you strategically employ slopes
and ramps to launch yourself through
breathtaking alien landscapes.
Story&#39;s a bit obtuse and not terribly present so conceptually it&#39;s,
like, one step up from a screen saver, but it made me nostalgic
for retro games like Skyroads or Spindizzy that&#39;re just about
exploring one satisfying core movement mechanic.
It&#39;s that but elevated with the spectacular environments modern
graphics can offer to make a somewhat hypnotic experience,
if not without low points.
I played through it twice to absorb the story better but only ended
up confirming that I really didn&#39;t want to play that
fucking jungle planet level again.
Solar Ash
Solar Ash is a game by the creators of Hyper Light Drifter who have
dropped their previous unique crunchy pixel art identity in favour of
going full 3d third person open world like everyone else.
That&#39;s right, they&#39;ve pulled the &quot;Risk of Rain&quot; gambit.
Still, it maintains Hyper Light Drifter&#39;s visual style in that everyone&#39;s
decked out in magenta and cyan like they&#39;ve all sworn fealty to the
Order of the Mostly Empty Colour Printer.
Gameplay-wise Solar Ash is all over the place.
It feels like a 3D Sonic game and Mario Galaxy and
Shadow of the Colossus all spent an evening together that none of
them are now willing to talk about.
If you&#39;ve only room in your roller skating in space budget
for one game then of the trilogy it&#39;s probably the one that&#39;s most
like a game-game if you see what I mean,
but there&#39;s something weirdly forgettable about it that&#39;s
hard to put my finger on.
The story is kinda hard to follow,
but more likely it&#39;s that the core gameplay never really
evolves beyond &quot;press button to roller skate&quot; and
&quot;press other button to roller skate a bit faster.&quot;
Oh christ I&#39;m running out of time
and I wrote down more titles than I thought.
Better hammer the rest out quickfire style.
Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth!
A Metroidvania with rather good pixel art,
reminiscent of Symphony of the Night but harder
and more visually confusing and with poorer environment design
and not as good.
Apparently it&#39;s a spin-off from some long-running Japanese fantasy
franchise so if you&#39;re more familiar with that maybe the story would
feel less like you&#39;re viewing it through a sheet of frosted glass.
Eastward!
Cartoon post-apocalyptic kinda Zelda-y kinda Earthbound-y kinda
Lisa the Painful but not quite as likely to induce
suicidal depression-y,
charming enough that it gripped me for a while but then the plot
started to feel like it wasn&#39;t going anywhere interesting fast enough
and its grip loosened enough that I made my escape.
Moonglow Bay
Like a light farming sim that went all in on the fishing minigame.
But where everyone&#39;s made of Duplo
and kinda look like they&#39;re ready to die.
F.I.S.T Forged in Shadow Torch
Another Metroidvania!
It was alright.
CHORVS
Also alright.
The Ascent
Yeeeeah.
Tales of Arise
Animeee.
Doctor Who: Edge of Reality
Oh (laughter)
I did play that, didn&#39;t I! (more laughter)
Ahhhh.
Fucking sucked.
*OUTRO MUSIC*
